Guaranteed order of all write operations across nodes or threads.
Leader-based atomic broadcast protocol used by ZooKeeper for all writes.
An in-memory data node in the ZooKeeper server.
In ZooKeeper, pattern where client requests sync followed by read to ensure all outstanding writes are completed before reading data.
when many clients are waiting to acquire a resource (e.g., a lock), even when only one client can acquire the resource. wasteful.
ZooKeeper server to which all write requests are forwarded. This server atomically broadcasts writes to all servers in cluster.
ZooKeeper server that can locally handle all read requests from memory, but forwards write requests to leader. Each client connects to only one of these for all requests.

Because ZooKeeper does not lock state to take snapshots, the snapshots may be in inconsistent state. However, because data is idempotent and servers replay events since start of snapshot, not a problem.
Instead of implementing coordination primatives, ZooKeeper provides functionality to allow services to compose their own primatives.
Using multiple buffers (say, file page cache and head-space caching). Can be useful (e.g., graphics), or can be wasteful or unintended.
API feature of Limnux to directly transfer bytes from file channel to a socket channel. Used by Kafka for efficiency.
A feature of Kafka where a group of one or more consumers jointly consume a set of subscribed topics, with each message only delivered to one consumer.
broker registry, consumer registry, ownership registry, offset registry
Ephemeral znode in Zookeeper for storing Kafka data on each broker's host name, port, topics, and partitions.
Ephemeral znode in Zookeeper for storing Kafka data listing consumer groups and associated topics
Ephemeral znode in Zookeeper for storing Kafka data on a given consumer group, mapping consumers to partitions
Persistent znode in Zookeeper for storing Kafka data on the offset for the last consumed message in the partition for each subscribed partition.
Cyclic redundancy check. (acronym) Error detection code used to detect accidental changes to data.
Separate test implementation from data, mitigating test code duplication.
Calculating complexity of code by counting the decision points within a block of code. Any score about 10 is considered complex.
